Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Cooperative Interference Management-A Fundamental Study

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Interference is a fundamental feature of the wireless medium and a major performance bottleneck in the engineering of wireless networks. However, the broadcast nature of the wireless medium which manifests itself in the form of interference can also be a benefit in disguise. It allows multiple nodes to receive a common signal and generates the potential for cooperation. Much of the fundamental research effort on the broadcast aspect so far has addressed these two aspects (interference and cooperation) separately. This project studies interference management and cooperation in a common context and a holistic manner.

The research conducted in this effort (a) looks for novel communication strategies that harness the broadcast advantage while minimizing its interfering nature; (b) looks to identify engineering contexts where the novel communication strategies provide the most gain over traditional approaches; and (c) looks to characterize novel fundamental outer bounds (beyond the cut-set ones) to rates of reliable network communication where cooperation and interference coexist. These goals are addressed by starting out with simple (but canonical) models of wireless networks featuring two unicast traffic under three formulations that cover a wide range of issues in wireless networks: (i) cooperative networks such as cellular networks, (ii) competitive networks or networks with restricted cooperation such as Wi-Fi, and(iii) heterogenous networks involving cognitive radios.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Interference is a fundamental phenomenon in wireless systems. Transmissions that share the same frequency, time and space naturally interfere with each other. Dealing with these interferences is critical to good and scalable performance in wireless sytems (say in cellular or WiFi systems). 

 

Traditional methods of interference management are power control (lowering the power of interfering transmissions) and/or making sure there is no simultaneous transmission at the same time and frequency in geographically close by locations. However, it is not clear if there are other approaches to interfernece management that could yield better performances. Finding such novel approaches as well as understanding the best possible performance (of any scheme) are the twin goals of this project. Given the ambitious nature of the project, we focus on small wireless networks, such as pair of interfering point-to-point links, a point-to-point link interfering with the downlink of a cellular wireless system, etc. 

 

Our main results has been the discovery of several novel interference mechanisms, which harness the fact that interference is not noise -- in other words, interference is actually a signal meant to be decoded by another receiver and this discrete nature of the signal can be harnessed to mitigate interference. Of specific note is our interactive alignment scheme that performs significantly better than state of the art schemes, and harnesses recent advances in radio circuits related to full duplex capabilities. 

 

The results have been published in major journals and conferences for experts in the area, as well as discussed at length at industry workshops and talks. Three PhD students have been partially funded by this proposal, with one of them now an assistant professor at the University of Washington at Seattle.
